intro: Ancistrorhynchus metteniae, commonly known as the yellow-bellied parrotfish, is a species of marine fish found in the Indo-Pacific region. It belongs to the family Scaridae and is characterized by its vibrant yellow body with a distinctive black stripe running from the eye to the tail. The plant-like structure of its mouth, known as a beak, is used for grazing on algae and coral. It plays a significant role in reef ecosystems by contributing to the maintenance of coral health through its feeding habits. This species is also notable for its ability to change color depending on its environment and social interactions.
